newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU expected to stall further on Yugoslavia pact.
newsitem.headline: EU expected to stall further on Yugoslavia pact.

text.p: EU foreign ministers are expected, in view of recent events, to continue to hold off on Friday from giving rump Yugoslavia the preferential trade status granted to other countries in the region, EU sources said on Thursday.
"In my view it is very unlikely that a positive decision will be taken tomorrow," one European Union diplomat said.

At their last meeting on November 25, EU foreign ministers agreed in principle to grant Serbia and Montenegro preferential trade treatment with the 15-country bloc -- but to delay implementation at least until their December 6 meeting.
EU sources said that the situation since then had not improved, rather the opposite.

The annulment of municipal election results, what the EU perceives as Belgrade's lack of assistance in pursuing alleged war criminals and continued tension over the Serb-governed Kosovo region are among reasons why the ministers are reluctant to act.
Students and opposition supporters have flooded central Belgrade on Wednesday for 18 days of demonstrations against the ruling Socialist Party of President President Slobodan Milosevic.

"It is very unlikely that the Council (of foreign ministers) would proceed with formal adoption of the decision taken in principle because of the situation," one EU source said, adding that there was a feeling that would send the wrong signal.
He added, however, that ministers would probably ask the European Commission to look at what the EU could do to support democratisation, using other instruments.
